newsitem.title: BELARUS: Belarus police detain two Americans, two Germans.
newsitem.headline: Belarus police detain two Americans, two Germans.

text.p: Two Americans and two Germans were detained during a protest in Belarus against President Alexander Lukashenko, state television said on Saturday.
A journalist who was arrested with three of the four foreigners on Friday said they had been released after several hours.
"Several people were arrested, including two American and two German citizens, for active participation in the protest," the television announcer said, quoting the interior ministry.

One of the Americans works for an international centre on cultural affairs in Minsk. The two Germans were working for a student newspaper and were members of the Green Party, the journalist, Roman Yakovlevsky, said.
"We were held for few hours. They took our fingerprints, filmed us and let us go," Yakovlevsky said.

Reuters correspondents saw about 50 people being bundled into lorries and police vehicles at Friday's protest, raising fears that a second protest planned for Saturday could also lead to confrontation with police.
The demonstrators had intended to proceed through the city, a move banned by the authorities.
Some protesters were beaten and looked dazed but there was no sign of bloodshed as police moved in to break up a gathering of up to 2,000 mostly young people.
Other journalists who had been detained at the rally also said they were held for a few hours and then released.

Lukashenko, facing growing unrest among opposition forces, has ordered restrictions on political meetings and banned his opponents from using post-independence national symbols, which he has scrapped in favour of old Soviet ones.
The United States said on Friday it had downgraded its relationship with Belarus because of what it called a "serious turn for the worse" in the human rights situation.
U.S. State Department spokesman Nicholas Burns said the government had imposed what he called severe restrictions on freedom of speech and assembly.
He noted that political party offices had been searched by police and cited strong-arm tactics against demonstrators.
Washington is concerned at plans for closer ties between Russia and Belarus which Russian President Boris Yeltsin said on Friday could even extend to a full merger one day.
